title: tribehacks ix
long_desc:
Hi Everyone! 
 It’s that time of year again; William & Mary’s very own student hackathon, TribeHacks IX, returns to Swem Library from April 20 to April 21, 2024. Historically the event has been attended by as many as 400 students from William & Mary and other schools in the surrounding area. There are plenty of opportunities for students to get involved, especially those with a passion for technology like you.
 First of all, we’re looking for students to lead workshops at the hackathon. The event is designed to accommodate all skill and experience levels, so we need a variety of workshops from absolute beginner to more advanced levels. If there’s something you’re passionate about, confident in, and/or interested in learning more about, please don’t hesitate to sign up to lead a workshop here! 

Second, our planning meetings are weekly in Tucker 222 from 6-7 PM on Mondays. This is a great time to ask questions or volunteer to help out on one or two of the many tasks that go into making this hackathon a rewarding experience for our attendees! We need day-of volunteers as well! Volunteers help pick up and set up the catered meals, answer attendee questions, and make sure that TribeHacks is a memorable experience for the attendees. Those who volunteered last year say that it was a highlight of their semester. If that sounds like something you’d like to do, fill out this interest form!

Lastly (and certainly most importantly), we need attendees! Our website, tribehacks.com, is live and accepting registrations to attend the hackathon. Please talk to your friends, and whether they have no idea what Python is or have been programming for years, we’d love for them to sign up to attend. We’ll have plenty of team-building games, programming challenges, free food, and lots of awesome people to meet. There will also be a career fair where attendees can meet recruiters looking for people with technical skills to work for their companies. It’s basically a giant Swem lock-in and will definitely be a weekend to remember.
 Aside from the fact that it is a ton of fun, a successful TribeHacks will have an array (no pun intended) of benefits for our CS department. A goal of TribeHacks this year is to make visible our identity as a Computer Science department at a liberal arts school, and all the unique benefits that identity brings to students. Student engagement in Computing and Data Science is super important in making sure William & Mary can continue to provide a great education in these in-demand areas for years to come. 
 The TribeHacks planning team would appreciate any and all involvement you can put in to help make this event a success. We hope to see you on Mondays at 6 PM or on April 20th! Thanks for your time!
 Best,
TribeHacks IX Planning Team
Sponsored by: Association for Computing Machinery, Developer Student Club at W&M, Robotics Club at William and Mary, and Society of Women in Computing

title: Williamsburg Jamestown Airport Tour
long_desc:
Please fill out this Google Form in order to receive more information about this event!
Tribe Aviation will be touring Williamsburg-Jamestown Airport (KJGG) on April 20th. We will start with a tour of Williamsburg Flight Center, which is the local flight school. Next we will meet with the VP of KJGG's local Experimental Aircraft Association. He will talk about the organization and show off his RV-7A! There will also be an opportunity to sit in a Cessna 172! Then we will speak to some of the airport staff and learn about the operation of the KJGG! Finally, we will enjoy lunch at Williamsburg Jamestown Airport's sandwich shop, Charly's!
Transportation from W&M is offered. Those who need transportation should check the box on the Google Form. Those who drive themselves can meet us at Williamsburg-Jamestown Airport at 10:00AM.
Please fill out this Google Form in order to receive more information about this event!
Sponsored by: Aviation Club

title: Out of the Darkness: Suicide Prevention Campus Walk
event_loc: McLeod Tyler Wellness Center, Social Wellness Patio
short_desc: A walk to prevent suicide and encourage help-seeking
long_desc:
Suicide is preventable and mental health is just as important as physical health. You, our Walkers, help make a difference. Join ATO to change the conversation, create a world without suicide, and support the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention (AFSP). Visit our website for more information on how to join or meet us on the Patio of the McLeod Tyler Wellness Center before the start of the walk.
Walk Registration: 10 a.m.
Walk Begins: 11 a.m.
Sponsored by: Alpha Tau Omega

title: Earth Day Bash '24
long_desc:
Earth Day Bash 2024 will be held on Saturday, April 20th from 11 AM-2 PM on Crim Dell Meadows. Come out to enjoy live music, free food, and tons of activities! There will be many student organizations and departments tabling with activities such as trivia, a pop-up thrift shop, and art projects. You might even leave the event with a new plant, stickers, and more. There will also be an upcycled art competition to vote on, which you can register to compete it at this link: https://forms.gle/NfDbL82UfCUHierc6, and the winners will be announced at the end of our event. 
All students, faculty, staff, and Williamsburg community members are invited to attend. Bring your family and friends for a day of fun and to celebrate our lovely Earth!
* In the chance of rain, the event will be held in the Miller Hall atrium. 
Event hosted by the Office of Sustainability and Student Assembly. 
Sponsored by: Committee on Sustainability: W&M Sustainability and Student Assembly

title: Dissertation Proposal - Kenneth Howard Koltermann, Computer Science
short_desc:
Dissertation Proposal - Kenneth Howard Koltermann, Computer Science
Title: Machine Learning and Wearable Computing for the Detection and Treatment of Neurological Diseases
Co-advisors: Dr. Gang Zhou
Zoom Link
long_desc:
Abstract:
Over the past decade, ubiquitous sensing has been increasingly explored as a viable means collect patient health data to improve how doctors can diagnose neurological disorders and diseases.  As machine learning methods continue to be improved by researchers from the computer science community, machine learning has seen a slower adoption by healthcare researchers to automatically detect and treat symptoms of neurological diseases such as Parkinson's disease. In this dissertation, I investigate how wearable computing and machine learning can be used to automatically detect and treat symptoms of Parkinson's disease (PD), freezing of gait (FoG) and hand tremors, in both real-time and offline settings.

First, we designed a FoG detection and treatment system, FoG-Finder, which combines ubiquitous sensing, mobile computing, and machine learning to automatically detect and treat FoG symptoms in real-time. We first created time and frequency domain features using domain knowledge about how FoG symptoms manifest. Then, we used a multi-input convolutional neural network (CNN) model on a smartphone for real-time inference of FoG/non-FoG gait. To evaluate FoG-Finder, we collected data from 11 (PD) patients consisting of 716 FoG events. FoG-Finder beat the previous state-of-the-art, obtaining a 13.4% higher F1 score and 10.7% higher overall accuracy compared with other validated real-time FoG detection and treatment systems in a leave-one-subject-out (LOSO) setting. FoG-Finder also obtained an average treatment latency of 427ms and 615ms for subject-dependent and LOSO settings, respectively, proving FoG-Finder to be a viable FoG detection and treatment system for real-world use by PD patients.

Second, we further improved real-time FoG detection by identifying that turns are the most common aspect of non-FoG gait falsely identified by prior FoG detection systems as FoG, leading to treatment application when it is not needed.  To address this revelation, we designed the Gait-Guard wearable FoG detection and treatment system.  The system generates hand-crafted features derived from domain knowledge about the various ways that PD patients can express turns during non-FoG gait, and uses a light-weight multivariate time-series transformer model capable of real-time inference on mobile hardware to detect FoG symptoms. We evaluated Gait-Guard on a dataset we collected consisting of 26 PD patients and a total of 1591 FoG events. Gait-Guard was able to obtain a FoG event accuracy of 96.5% with a reduction in the false positive treatment rate of 112% compared to prior real-time FoG detection works including FoG-Finder. Gait-Guard is demonstrated to work for real-time treatments with an average FoG detection latency of just 378.5ms in a LOSO setting.

Third, we are currently studying how real-time FoG detection models can be adapted to supply accurate FoG labels to automate the clinical FoG labeling process. We collected a FoG-rich dataset containing 41 PD patients while they walked through the five most common FoG triggering scenarios. We plan to combine a rules-based approach derived from domain knowledge about the FoG labeling process with machine learning to accurately provide start and end times to FoG time segments, something that no other research work has addressed.

Finally, we will explore how wearable computing and machine learning can automatically detect and treat PD hand tremor symptoms in real-time, and leverage the real-time inference of our machine learning models to supply accurate hand tremor labels to clinicians in an offline setting. This will further improve how PD clinicians can monitor and treat their patients. Overall, we utilized wearable computing and machine learning to facilitate the detection and treatment of symptoms of Parkinson's disease. Our results show that combining wearable computing and machine learning can improve how PD clinicians monitor and treat their patients.

Bio:
Kenneth Howard Koltermann is a Ph.D. candidate in the Computer Science Department at William & Mary, under the supervision of Prof. Gang Zhou. His research focuses on wearable computing and machine learning for healthcare. His Ph.D. research has been published in IEEE/ACM CHASE 2023 and 2024. He is a recipient of an Entrepreneur-in-Residence grant at William & Mary and is currently working on commercialization of his research through the startup Motion Medix LLC. He received his master's degree in computer science from William & Mary and his bachelor's degree in computer science from California State University, East Bay.


Sponsored by: Computer Science

title: Acupuncture Lounge
event_loc: McLeod Tyler Wellness Center, Studio B
short_desc: The Acupuncture Lounge is the first of its kind in Williamsburg. This model of care removes as many barriers as possible to accessible treatments ensuring a stable and reliable supply of affordable acupuncture for the WM and local community.
long_desc:
The Acupuncture Lounge is your go-to, one-stop place to reset your nervous system when you are feeling stressed and overwhelmed. Sitting or lying down in a large room overlooking nature, the Licensed Acupuncturists will use micro-sized, one-time use, sterile stainless steel, filiform needles in the ear or distal location (elbows to fingers, knees to toes, or scalp) in a group setting to induce a relaxation response. You will then rest with the needles in for about 20-30 minutes. From beginning to end, the total appointment lasts approximately 30-45 min.
Sponsored by: Mcleod Tyler Wellness Center

title: Earth Day Panel: Michael P. Branch '85 and Dean King
short_desc: W&M Libraries and the Institute for Integrative Conservation & Office of Sustainability have partnered together to host award-winning authors, Michael Branch '85 and Dean King for an Earth Day panel discussion.
long_desc:
W&M Libraries and the Institute for Integrative Conservation & Office of Sustainability have partnered together to host award-winning authors,  Michael Branch '85 and Dean King for an Earth Day panel discussion. There will be a book signing following the talk, and the W&M Spirit Shop & Bookstore will be on site selling copies. Light refreshments will be available.  Please register using the link below. Free and open to all!

About the authors:
Mike Branch '85 is a W&M alum, writer, humorist, environmentalist, father, and desert rat who lives with his wife and two young daughters in the western Great Basin Desert. His work includes nine published books, one of which is the Pulitzer Prize-nominated John Muir’s Last Journey: South to the Amazon and East to Africa (Island Press). Mike, who is Professor of Literature and Environment and University Foundation Professor at the University of Nevada, Reno, is co-founder and past president of the Association for the Study of Literature and Environment (ASLE), served for sixteen years as the Book Review Editor of ISLE: Interdisciplinary Studies in Literature and Environment, and is a co-founder and series co-editor of the University of Virginia Press book series Under the Sign of Nature: Explorations in Ecocriticism. He is the recipient of Ellen Meloy Desert Writers Award, the Nevada Writers Hall of Fame Silver Pen Award, the Western Literature Association Frederick Manfred Award for Creative Writing, the Willa Pilla Award for Humor Writing, and his books have been finalists for the Sigurd Olson Nature Writing Award, the Association for the Study of Literature and Environment Creative Book Award, and the Mountain West Center Evans-Handcart Award. 
Dean King is an award-winning author of ten nonfiction books. Dean relishes the adventures involved in making history come to life while at the same time diligently searching out the truth and turning up new historical detail. While researching his national bestseller Skeletons on the Zahara, he crossed the Sahara on camels and in Land Rovers. He trekked the Long March trail in the Snowy Mountains of Western China while researching Unbound and was shot at in Appalachia while writing The Feud. For his most recent book, Guardians of the Valley, Dean traveled to John Muir’s boyhood homes in Dunbar, Scotland, and rural Wisconsin and spent months roaming Yosemite National Park and the Sierra Nevada. Dean’s writing has also appeared in the Daily Telegraph, Granta, Garden & Gun, National Geographic Adventure, Outside, Travel + Leisure, New York, the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal and Virginia Living. He is a partner in Gum Street Productions, making documentary films.

Sponsored by: W&M Libraries and Institute for Integrative Conservation & Office of Sustainability

title: Earth Day at VIMS: Plein Air Paint Along and Demonstration
event_loc: VIMS - Davis Hall, Riverfront Lawn behind Davis Hall; 7539 Spencer Rd, Gloucester Point, VA 23062
short_desc: Join VIMS on Earth Day (4/22) from 5-8 PM on the Riverfront Lawn for a paint-along, mini-workshop, and "plein air" (open air) painting demonstration with award-winning American Impressionist painter Tricia Bass of Evergreen, Colorado (www.TriciaBass.com).
long_desc:
Award-winning American Impressionist painter Tricia Bass of Evergreen, Colorado will be hosting a paint-along, mini-workshop and “plein air” (French for open air) painting demonstration on Monday, April 22nd (Earth Day!) from 5:00 – 8:00 PM on the Riverfront Lawn of the Virginia Institute of Marine Science (VIMS) in Gloucester Point, VA. This event is free to the public but attendees must register using the link below. Participants can bring their own easel and painting supplies or they can try their hand with painting on one of two shared easels. A suggested supply list will be sent to attendees upon registration. Observers are also welcome, please bring your own chair. This is an event geared toward adults but a limited number of children may attend if accompanied by a parent or caregiver.
Bass is a visiting guest artist and advisor for a future, planned artist-in-residency program to be hosted yearly by VIMS. She paints the American west with a colorful, painterly style and is excited about painting in and around the Chesapeake Bay. Tricia is a signature member of Plein Air Artists of Colorado and spends a great deal of time painting “en plein air” throughout the Rocky Mountain west. She is also a member of the national Women Artists of the West and the American Impressionist Society. Tricia’s work can be viewed on her website at www.TriciaBass.com.



Sponsored by: VIMS Marine Advisory Program & VIMS Communications and Marketing

title: Giving and Receiving Feedback
short_desc: This workshop will provide techniques and approaches to both giving and receiving feedback.
long_desc:
Giving and receiving feedback is hard. It is hard to know how to start a conversation, what to do when the conversation starts to go awry, and how to ensure the conversation is healthy and productive. This workshop will cover these topics and provide time for practice both giving and receiving feedback.
Sponsored by: University Human Resources

No art experience is necessary; the focus is on self-expression and connecting with others. Gain insight into your emotions, learn new coping skills, and process feelings with peers in a supportive environment. Led by Certified Art Therapist, Sarah Balascio.

Dr. Freeman will talk to scholars about his journey from W&M student to the owner of a successful medical practice, and how he navigated medical school, residency and beyond. Dr. Freeman, who has been practicing general pediatrics in the Richmond community for the past 18 years, opened Old Dominion Pediatrics in August of 2012. title: The Milton & Shirley G. Salasky Lecture -- Professor Piero Capelli
short_desc: Join the Judaic Studies Program for The Milton & Shirley G. Salasky Lecture!
long_desc:
"A Source of Shame and Horror: Discovering, Translating, and Burning the Talmud in Medieval Christian Europe" by Professor Piero Capelli
At Paris in 1240, the Babylonian Talmud underwent a public trial that spurred a number of significant landmarks in Jewish, Christian and European history. Not least was the first translation of Talmud into a non-Jewish language, Latin. But more telling was the first attested burning of Jewish books in history, an event that launched a long tradition of Christian censorship and persecution against Rabbinic lore.
Piero Capelli is Professor of Hebrew in the Department of Asian and North African Studies at Ca’ Foscari University of Venice. A scholar of late antique and medieval Judaism, he is the author of two important Italian monographs on Rabbinic Judaism: Rabbinic Literature from the Time of Jesus to the Closing of Talmud (1996) and Evil: The History of an Idea in Judaism from the Bible to Qabbalah (2012).

Sponsored by: Judaic Studies Program

title: Women's Creativity Group for Faculty & Staff
event_loc: McLeod Tyler Wellness Center, Studio B
long_desc:
Developed for female faculty and staff, the class is held at the McLeod Tyler Wellness Center and focuses on art and wellness. It provides a casual setting where female employees can drop-in and step away from work during lunchtime to explore and reflect on topics related to women, careers, and work-life balance in a supportive and uplifting environment. Participants will have an opportunity to explore a variety of art materials with some guidance from a creative arts therapist. No art-making experience is necessary, just a willingness to notice how good it feels to step away from work for a bit!
Every Wednesday at 12pm at the McLeod Tyler Wellness Center.

title: Pet therapy with Norman
short_desc: Come say hi to our new therapy dog, Norman, for some destressing between classes.
long_desc:
Norman is a rescue dog and was found in a farmer's field in Kentucky. He is a 6 year old Great Pyrenees who loves children, other dogs, and pretty much everyone!  Stop by for pet therapy and puppy love!
Sponsored by: Mcleod Tyler Wellness Center

title: Supportive Workshop: Test Anxiety Solutions
event_loc: McLeod Tyler Wellness Center, Studio A
long_desc:
Have you struggled with taking exams? Do you feel that your test performance would improve if you had a better approach for managing your thinking and emotions around tests? Our Performance Psychology Director will lead a workshop designed to help you improve your reactions to testing situations, prepare in an intentional way, and execute with more confidence on the day of the exam.
Participants will learn about threats to clear thinking in evaluation situations.
Participants will examine new strategies for preparation and execution for important grading situations.
Participants will consider their own reactions to evaluation, and learn strategies to “manage the moments” of distress.
Content of the workshop emphasizes gaining perspective on the experience of test anxiety in a way that promotes a less anxious and more confident attitude toward managing fears.
Sponsored by: Counseling Center

title: Reproductive and Maternal Health Panel Watch Party
long_desc:
Join us for a live panel discussion on maternal health, infertility, and reproductive health in the Black community, and the social determinants of health that have led to poor reproductive and maternal health outcomes for African American women. Plus discussion on Virginia & Federal laws that impact access to reproductive and maternal health services and advocate to improve health outcomes.
Sponsored by: Alpha Kappa Alpha

title: Being Black in Asia: Study Abroad Panel Discussion and Info Session
long_desc:
Interested in learning more about the Black student experience in an Asian country? Or studying abroad in general? Come to the Being Black in Asia Study Abroad Panel Discussion and Info Session! Come listen to Black students who have studied abroad in various Asian countries and ask questions about their experiences! Topics that will be addressed include care, interactions with locals, travel tips, scholarships, and more! Join us in Washington 306 on Wednesday, April 24th, from 6:45pm to 8pm. Pizza will be provided! All are welcome, so bring your friends!
Please RVSP here: https://forms.gle/XsMt1XeC5QqkiT9j8
For questions, contact: Abena Konadu (akonadu@wm.edu)
Sponsored by: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc.

title: SA Finance Department Office Hours
long_desc:
The Student Assembly Finance Department is pleased to share that we will be holding weekly office hours for students to attend. Office Hours will be held by each Undersecretary of Finance and the Secretary of Finance. Our goal is to ensure you have the ability to ask any and all questions you may have about the OBAC funding process. The purpose of these Office Hours is to help educate Registered Student Organizations on the intricacies of our quarterly budget allocation process while also promoting transparency! 
Sponsored by: Organization Budget Allocation Committee and Student Assembly

title: Pet Therapy With Stella
long_desc:
Stella and her handler, Dr. Mark Sullivan will be at the McLeod Tyler Wellness Center each Tuesday and Thursday from 11 AM - 1 PM. Stop by the Lobby to spend some time with Stella and a dose of Pet Therapy. 
Sponsored by: Mcleod Tyler Wellness Center

title: FitWell Class: Mindful Arts with Sarah
event_loc: McLeod Tyler Wellness Center, Studio A
short_desc: Experience Art Therapy as we mix mindfulness with creativity, designing works of art as a way to calm the mind and gain focus.
long_desc:
Experience Art Therapy as we mix mindfulness with creativity, designing works of art as a way to calm the mind and gain focus. At each class, you'll be guided through various techniques, use different mediums, and learn the basic skills of mindfulness.
Everyone is welcome! Neither art nor mindfulness experience is necessary to join!
Register in the W&M Wellness App or at wellness.wm.edu by searching "mindful" in the top search bar.
Sarah Balascio is a registered board-certified art therapist with a M.A. in Education and in Art Therapy. She is an adjunct lecturer and facilitates groups at the McLeod Tyler Wellness Center. She creates opportunities for students to express themselves through art in a supportive and mindful environment where they connect with themselves and their W&M community. Creative Arts groups are welcoming to all students, no experience is necessary just a willingness to experiment!

title: FGLI End of Year Celebration & Senior Recognition
long_desc:
Join us in celebrating FGLI students and their successes from the 2023-24 year! Graduating seniors will be recognized (if desired) and presented with their FGLI cord
This event is open to everyone (including FGLI mentors and mentees, faculty/professional staff, graduate students, etc.).
There will be guest speakers, food, fun, and celebrations. A more detailed itinerary will soon be made available soon. Semi-formal attire is encouraged but definitely not required.
You can RSVP HERE.
Sponsored by: Student Transition Engagement Programs of W&M

title: ASL Club Meeting
long_desc:
Interested in American Sign Language? Want to learn more about Deaf culture? Looking for a place to practice signing while meeting new people? Join us in James Blair Hall Room 229 on Thursdays at 8PM to learn some basic ASL, improve your conversational skills, and more!!
Sponsored by: American Sign Language Club

title: Puppy Pride Party
long_desc:
Come rest and relax with the therapy puppies alongside your queer friends! This event is co-hosted by the Wellness Center.
Sponsored by: Lambda Alliance

title: GSWS Faculty Colloquia with Dr. Brett Wilson, Nothing’s Straight in Tristram Shandy
long_desc:
Prof. Wilson will discuss how Laurence Sterne’s 1759 novel Tristram Shandy reclaims the squiggly, eccentric, erratic, and failed in order to question the imperative for both novels and people to be straight. Brett D. Wilson is associate professor and chair of English at William & Mary. He is author of A Race of Female Patriots: Women and Public Spirit on the British Stage, 1688-1745 (Bucknell University Press, 2012). His articles on British 18th-century drama and poetry have appeared in ELH, Eighteenth-Century Studies, and in the essay collections Invoking Slavery in the Eighteenth-Century British Imagination (Ashgate, 2013) and Patriarchal Moments (Bloomsbury Academic, 2015). He is currently at work on a monograph, The Absent Governor.
Sponsored by: Gender, Sexuality & Women's Studies

title: Grad Bell Ringing
long_desc:
Reception for graduating graduate students after bell ringing
Sponsored by: Graduate Council

title: Grad Student Bell Ringing
short_desc: Ringing the Wren Bell at the end of one's academic journey is a cherished William & Mary tradition!
long_desc:
Ringing the Wren Bell at the end of one's academic journey is a cherished William & Mary tradition!
Line-up will begin outside the courtyard fence (on the Sunken Garden side of the Wren Building). Volunteers will be there to assist.
A hand wash station is there for you to wash upon entering Wren.
No food or drink is permitted inside the Wren Building
The entire process should take anywhere from 5-15 minutes, depending on how many students are ringing the bell.
We hope students will share their experience!
Students may tag their public Twitter and Instagram photos with #wmgrad and the photos might be included in the pre-ceremony slideshows in Zable Stadium and on the #wmGrad social wall.
Private Instagram account? Share photos with us via Box and we'll post them publicly for you.

Sponsored by: Commencement Planning Committee

title: Order of Omega Popsicle Sale
event_loc: Sadler Terrace (or Atrium if it rains)
long_desc:
Cool down with us! Order of Omega is hosting a popsicle sale at Sadler on April 26th. Satisfy your sweet tooth and support the FSL community!
Sponsored by: Order of Omega

title: Japan Studies Research Colloquium & お別れ会
short_desc: Join us as Japanese Studies Majors present their final research projects for the Japanese Studies Senior Colloquium.  We will also present year-end awards in Japanese Studies and enjoy some snacks!
long_desc:
Join the Japanese Studies Program for our ceremony to mark the end of the academic year, the Japanese Studies Senior Colloquium and O-wakare-kai.  Eight Japanese Studies Majors will present their final research projects in two panels. We will also present year-end awards in Japanese Studies, take commemorative photographs, enjoy some snacks, celebrate our graduating seniors and wish them well! We have a fascinating and impressive slate of presentations, including:
Claire Colley: The Aestheticization of Religious Imagery in the Japanese Music Genre Visual Kei
Ryleigh Line: How to Fill a Void: Exploring Pro-Natalism and Social Isolation in Japan through Emi Yagi's Diary of a Void
Chase Packer: Accepting Catastrophe: Suzume and the Aftermath of Disaster
Aiden Sanders: Representations of a New Generation in Tanaka Yasuo's Somehow Crystal: Youth Culture's Relationship with Politics and Wealth
Gabriella Shelton: Representations of Disease & Economy in Sweet Bean
Emma Willis: Selling the Schoolgirl in Post-Bubble Japan: A Cultural Analysis of Bounce Ko Gals
Ruini Wu: Precarious Self, Love, and Consumerism: A Study of We Made a Beautiful Bouquet
Annemarie Zheng: Depiction of Isolation and Suicide in Ruth Ozeki's A Tale for the Time Being

Sponsored by: Japanese Studies Program

title: Demos in the Sun
long_desc:
Come out to the Small Hall Lawn to have fun with Physics! We'll have kinds of fun demos, from oobleck to 3-D bubbles to slinkies and liquid nitrogen ice cream! Stop by anytime between 3:30 and 5 on Friday, April 26th!
Sponsored by: Society of Physics Students

title: The UN and Regional Nuclear Nonproliferation
short_desc: Why do regions seek to ban nuclear weapons? What challenges do they face? What role can the United Nations play? Where will success come next? Izumi Nakamitsu, UN Under-Secretary-General & High Representative for Disarmament Affairs will discuss.
long_desc:
Regional nuclear-weapon-free zones have been a staple of nonproliferation efforts since the mid-1950s. Over the past 60 years, eight regions have been denuclearized under international law. To date, these agreements cover roughly 120 countries, most of the southern hemisphere, and close to two billion people.
Why do regions seek to ban nuclear weapons? What challenges do they face? What role can the United Nations play? And where will success come next? Please join the Global Research Institute for a conversation around these topics with Ms. Izumi Nakamitsu, UN Under-Secretary-General and High Representative for Disarmament Affairs. The event will take place at Tucker Theater on Friday, April 26 from 5 pm to 6 pm. RSVPs requested.



Sponsored by: Global Research Institute

title: Jamnesty
long_desc:
Come to W&M Amnesty International's annual fundraising concert: Jamensty! We will be having live performers and raising money for the Richmond International Rescue Committee (https://www.rescue.org/united-states/richmond-va), which helps settle refugees in the Richmond area. 
Sponsored by: Amnesty International - W&M Chapter

title: 7th Grade Sketch Comedy Presents: 7 THINGS I HATE ABOUT thGRADE SKETCH COMEDY
long_desc:
Come out this Friday, April 26th to Ewell Recital Hall for our last show of the semester. We will be performing the seniors' favorite sketches of the past four years, along with some fresh new sketches never before seen on stage. Tears will be shed. Lives will be changed. You will cry out of laughter and out of sentimentality because the seniors are leaving. You do not want to miss this. 
Sponsored by: 7th Grade Sketch Comedy

title: Salsa Club Showcase 2024
long_desc:
Our annual showcase with performances from (and created by) students! Featuring several of the different styles taught in the club, this event is how Salsa Club showcases all we've learned in the past year.
Sponsored by: Salsa Club
